snippet: France’s president-elect, François Hollande, may be better aligned with the United States on economic matters, yet more likely to differ on diplomatic and military affairs.
abstract: United States has lost one of its closest allies in Europe with French Pres Nicolas Sarkozy's defeat at the hands of Socialist presidential candidate Francois Hollande, but Hollande's economic policy beliefs may more closely align with those of the US. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- With the victory of the Socialist candidate, François Hollande, in the French presidential election, the White House has lost one of its closest allies on the Continent, but perhaps gained one with economic policy beliefs more closely aligned with its own. Mr. Hollande is virtually unknown in Washington, and his policy positions on both domestic and international affairs remain only lightly sketched out. That is in stark contrast to the departing president, Nicolas Sarkozy, whose frequent discussions with and ardent defense of the White House earned him the nickname ''Sarko the American'' back home.

headline.main: Change in Paris May Better Fit U.S. Economic Positions
